sa1.11-14:0.2: (11-14) Past Is Impermanent, Painful, Empty, and Not Self
sa1.11-14:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī.
sa1.11-14:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa1.11-14:2.2: “Past and future form is [11] impermanent … [12] painful … [13] empty … [14] not self, so why wouldn’t present form?
sa1.11-14:2.3: Noble disciples thus observe them, not looking back to past form and not wishing for future form.
sa1.11-14:2.4: They tire and become free of desire for present form, being correctly oriented toward its cessation.
sa1.11-14:2.8: consciousness is [11] impermanent … [12] painful … [13] empty … [14] not self, so why wouldn’t present consciousness?
sa1.11-14:2.9: Noble disciples thus observe them, not looking back to past consciousness and not wishing for future consciousness.
sa1.11-14:2.10: They tire and become free of desire for present consciousness, being correctly oriented toward its cessation.”
sa1.11-14:3.1: The monks who heard what the Buddha taught then rejoiced and approved.
